overview: The purpose of this measure remains to increase the cigarette tax and allocate the increase to the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund. Your Committee has amended this measure by changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt). The Department of the Attorney General asks that this Committee change the defective effective date to the original effective date of July 1, 2025 (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt).
assumptions_and_methodology: Your Committee finds that cigarette smoking remains the leading cause of preventable death nationally, and is linked to heart disease, cancer, and stroke (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt). According to the United States Surgeon General, increasing the price of tobacco products is the single most effective way to reduce consumption (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt). Testimony projects that a $1.00 (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) per pack cigarette tax increase in Hawaiʻi will generate $10.84 million (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) in new revenue in its first year.
agency_impact: The Department of Taxation requests that the effective date be amended to January 1, 2026 to provide sufficient time for DOTAX to update stamps and implement the system and form changes necessary for the proposed increase (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt). The Department of the Attorney General's Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund (Fund) has experienced a revenue decline; revenue deposited into the Fund has dropped from $1.74 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in fiscal year 2015-2016 to $1.03 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in 2023-2024. Hawaii received over $36.4 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in MSA payments for fiscal year 2023-2024, and recent arbitration decisions highlight a critical need for stable funding for the Department to maintain and further its diligent enforcement efforts and reduce the risk of losing MSA revenue (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt).
economic_impact: The annual estimated health care costs directly caused by smoking in Hawaii is $611 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt). Smoking-caused government expenditures result in a tax burden of $955.00 (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) per household and $1.1 billion (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) in lost productivity in Hawaii. Testimony projects a $1.00 (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) per pack increase would save the state more than $31.8 million (HB441_TESTIMONY_HLT_01-29-25_.PDF.txt) in long-term health care costs.
policy_impact: The Committee on Health is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 441, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 441, H.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Higher Education (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt).
revenue_sources: Testimony from the Department of the Attorney General indicates that cigarette tax stamp revenues have plummeted, from over $116 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in fiscal year 2015-2016 to just over $70 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in fiscal year 2023-2024. This decline has affected the funding for the University of Hawaii Cancer Center, community health centers, trauma centers, and emergency medical services (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt). Total cigarette revenue for FY24 was $70,092,426 (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt).
operating_revenue_impact: The Department’s Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund revenue has dropped from $1.74 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in fiscal year 2015-2016 to $1.03 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in 2023-2024. The Department needs to recuperate funding to the Fund to ensure continued diligent enforcement of the Master Settlement Agreement (MSA) (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt).
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Committee on Health has amended the measure by changing the effective date to July 1, 3000 (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt), which defers long-term fiscal implications until the date is amended.
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The Committee on Health amended the measure, changing the effective date from December 31, 2050 to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion (HB441_HD1_HSCR27_.PDF.txt). New testimony quantifies the decline in cigarette tax stamp revenues from over $116 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in FY 2015-2016 to just over $70 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in FY 2023-2024. Additional testimony specifies the revenue decline in the Department of the Attorney General's Tobacco Enforcement Special Fund, which dropped from $1.74 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) to $1.03 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) over the same period, potentially jeopardizing the enforcement needed to secure over $36.4 million (HB441_HD1_.HTM.txt) in annual MSA payments.
